remark.ch:
Prerequisites for this course include:
- Japanese syllabary (五十音),
- basic Japanese grammar,
- intermediate Japanese listening and speaking,
- intermediate Japanese reading and writing.

goal.en: This course aims to achieve following goals at the end of the semester. 1. proficient Japanese listening and speaking 2. proficient Japanese reading and writing 3. ability to describe about introductory science in Japanese 4. ability to join the discussion about introductory science in Japanese

content.en:
This course divides the time in the classroom into three parts.
Part A:
The first 20 min is used for listening of short articles. Each
week, two short articles are chosen from Japanese popular science
magazines. A-half-page or one-page articles about recent news in
the field of natural science are used for this part. The
instructor (Kinoshita Daisuke) read those articles without
passing these articles to students. Students listen to those
articles, and talk about what they understand. After the
discussion, articles are provided to students, so that they can
check whether they successfully grab the overall meaning of the
articles.
Part B:
Next 80 min is used for reading of longer articles. Each week,
one article is chosen from Japanese popular science
magazines. Two-page or four-page articles about natural science are
used for this part. An article is passed to students at the
beginning of this part. The instructor (Kinoshita Daisuke) read
about 70％ of the article. Then, students and I discuss about
content of the article. Students can also ask questions about
meaning of words, grammar, and article content. After the
discussion, the instructor lets students to read the rest of the
article.
Part C:
Last 50 min is used for the practice of compositions of short
sentences. Each week, the instructor selects 15-20 commonly used
expressions and phrases from the articles, and pass the problem-set to
students. Students try to make a sentence for each expression in
the classroom. Students present the sentences they have made, and
the instructor (Kinoshita Daisuke) provide suggestions if any.
At the end of the class:
At the end of the class, a homework is passed to students.
